section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Gather drawing paper and drawing tools.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story Alma and How She Got Her Name. In the story, Alma’s father shows her pictures of people in their family and tells her stories about them. Alma learns about what each one liked to do or what they are known for. Explain to children what it means to be “known for” something.
In this activity, you will draw a picture of yourself. You will show yourself doing something you like to do or something that you would like to be known for.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Provide Support Distribute drawing materials to each child. Tell children to think about what they will show in their pictures. Provide ideas. For example, children might draw themselves with a pet or favorite toy. They might show themselves as an astronaut in space or as a doctor or basketball player. Invite children to share their own ideas of what they might draw.
Draw Allow children time to complete their drawings. Tell them to write their names on their papers, providing help as needed.
Share Portraits Invite children to show their self-portraits and tell a story about what they drew.
Make a Book Create a book of children’s work. Leave it in your classroom library for children to look at during free time.

For children who need a little more help, speak with them individually. For example ask, What is something you love to do? How can you show that in your drawing? Ask, What is something special about you? How can you show that in your drawing?
Invite children to dictate a sentence that tells a story about what they drew. Ask children to give you labels for the people and/or objects in their drawings.

After children have finished drawing, invite them to point to and name the objects, people, or colors in their drawings. Have the children name those objects in English and then repeat the words after you.

As children tell the stories about their drawings, comment about sensory details or ask questions that elicit answers about sensory details. For example, say: Your cat looks very soft. How does it feel when you hug your cat? Does your cat ever make sounds? What sounds does your cat make?

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story Alma and How She Got Her Name, and we talked about building relationships. Alma’s father helped Alma by telling her about all the people she is named after. He helped Alma by telling her stories about those family members.
When we build relationships, we make and keep friendships with and get closer to our family and friends.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of people. We will decide whether the picture shows if they have a good or a bad relationship.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Hand Signals When you show each card, ask children to give a thumbs-up if they think the picture shows a good relationship or a thumbs-down if they think it shows a bad relationship.

Ask Show a picture and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed. Go through the cards one at a time, asking children to identify what kind of relationship they see in the picture.
Sort Give the picture card to children to put into one of two piles: Good Relationship or Bad Relationship.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When you look at the picture, how can you tell if a relationship is good or bad? What do you notice about people in a good relationship?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Invite children to talk about ways to have good relationships with family members or friends. Work with children to develop a class list of traits that help make good relationships, such as being a good listener, being kind, and being helpful.
Explain to children that the picture on the front of each card shows only the moment when the picture was taken. Ask: What do you think happens before and after the picture was taken?

There may be cultural differences in what people consider to be qualities of good relationships with family, friends, or acquaintances. Be sensitive to such differences and stress throughout this activity that there is not one right way to build relationships with others. Nevertheless, be sure to discuss basic aspects of respect and kindness that need to be present.

Teach the children the song “The More We Get Together” and sing it together. Make up additional lyrics, such as “The more we [play, laugh, share, help, talk, smile] together, the happier we’ll be.” Find additional children’s songs about friendship and play them for the children. Talk about what they heard in the songs that they could add to their class list of the qualities of good relationships.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story Alma and How She Got Her Name and saw how each of Alma’s relatives had different things they liked to do. Sofia liked books, Esperanza liked to learn about other places, José liked art, and so on. Alma felt better about her very long name when she realized she liked something that each of the people she is named after liked.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of children doing something they like. I will pick a card and we will act out what we see.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show a picture and ask the question on the back of the card, offering support. Go through the cards one at a time, guiding children to act out the activities they see.

Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card. After the class has acted out all the activities, invite children to act out one of the activities and have their classmates guess what they are doing.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-talk-emphasis: Take a survey of class interests by asking questions. For example, hold up a card and say, Raise your hand if you like [playing catch]. Then ask appropriate follow-up questions to extend the discussion.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Show children the pages in Alma and How She Got Her Name that tell about what Alma’s family members liked to do. Discuss the illustrations. Ask children questions to elicit responses about things they like or like to do. Help children decide how to act out one activity.
Ask: Which activity can you act out with a partner? Invite partners to discuss what they might act out together. Give partners time to plan before they act out an activity for the class to guess.
Model how to act out an activity that you like while naming it. For example, say, I like to read. or I like to run. or I like to paint. Then have children repeat your actions and words.

Children who have difficulty focusing while sitting still will benefit from standing and acting out activities with their classmates. Encourage children to watch you closely in order to copy the actions they see.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials You will need one sheet of paper and drawing tools for each child.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the poster I like to… and we learned about different things that different children like to do.
We learned the word square. Let’s revisit that word since that has something to do with what we’ll be doing today.
ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-talk-emphasis: Use the square Vocabulary Card to revisit the word.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will draw squares and then use them as picture frames. Then inside the square we will draw pictures of what we like to do.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Ask children to draw a square on a piece of paper. Draw a square for children to use as a model or help them with their drawing.
Discuss Now have children look at the I like to . . . poster and talk about things they like to do.
Draw Have children draw a picture inside the square of one thing they like to do.
Talk About It Invite children to talk about their pictures and explain what their drawings show. Encourage children to note any similarities with the things that their classmates like to do.

Make a Class Poster Have children help you to make a personalized I like to . . . poster for your class using their drawings. Have them dictate short descriptions for you to write as captions under their drawings.
Encourage children to describe what they’re doing as they add details to their drawing inside the squares. Ask questions about what children like to do in order to inspire ideas for their frames.

Ask children what other shapes they know. Have them draw a different shape on the back of their paper and then draw a picture inside that shape of something else they like to do. Have children dictate a description that can be used as a caption for their drawings.

Allow children time for peer-to-peer conversation as they work on their pictures. Remind them to take turns speaking, with one person actively listening while the other speaks. Remind children that it’s okay to use their home language when talking with a peer who also speaks that language.

Have children work on movements that go along with their pictures of what they like to do. Have them practice acting out the actions shown in their pictures and then sharing these movements with the class. Have classmates take turns guessing what the child drew inside the square based on what they see.
